ğŸ“˜ Practice 5 - Context-Based Passive Formation

Write appropriate passive sentences for these contexts:

  1. A news headline about a peace agreement between two countries

  2. A sentence in a scientific paper describing a laboratory procedure

  3. A diplomatic statement about a controversial political decision

  4. A sentence in a company email about project delays

  5. A museum placard describing when and where an artifact was discovered

  6. A sentence in a restaurant review about the quality of service

  7. A sentence in a legal document about property ownership

  8. A sentence in a historical text about a famous battle

ğŸ” Deep Review

The passive voice is a grammatical construction that shifts the focus from the doer of an action to the receiver. Here's a summary of key points:

  • Passive voice follows the structure: subject + form of "be" + past participle (+ by + agent)

  • It can be formed in all tenses and with modal verbs

  • The passive voice is appropriate when:

    • The action is more important than the doer

    • The doer is unknown, unimportant, or obvious

    • In scientific, academic, and technical writing

    • To be diplomatic or impersonal

    • To maintain the same subject throughout a paragraph

  • Brazilian learners face specific challenges with passive voice:

    • English uses passive more frequently in formal contexts

    • Portuguese often uses "se" constructions instead

    • Forming complex tense passives can be difficult

    • The "get" passive doesn't have a direct equivalent in Portuguese

  • While passive voice is valuable in many contexts, active voice is generally preferred for clarity and directness in most everyday communication

Quick Review Questions:

ğŸ¤¿ Conditionals

ğŸ” Review

In our previous lesson, we explored the passive voice in English. We examined how to form passive constructions in different tenses, when to use passive voice appropriately, and the specific challenges Brazilian learners face with this grammatical structure.

Quick Practice:

  1. Transform this active sentence into passive: "The committee will announce the results tomorrow."

  2. When is it appropriate to use the passive voice in English?

  3. What's one key difference between passive voice in English and Portuguese?

ğŸ¯ Overview

Conditional sentences express hypothetical situations and their consequences. They typically consist of two clauses: a condition (usually beginning with "if") and a result. English has several types of conditionals, each expressing different degrees of possibility, probability, or unreality.

The main conditional types include zero conditionals (general truths), first conditionals (possible future situations), second conditionals (hypothetical or unlikely present/future situations), third conditionals (impossible past situations), and mixed conditionals (combining different time references). Each type follows specific patterns of verb tenses in both clauses.

We use conditionals to discuss possibilities, make predictions, express regrets about the past, give advice, and talk about imaginary situations. Understanding the nuances between different conditional types is crucial for expressing precise meanings in English, especially since the tense patterns often differ from those used in Portuguese conditional structures.

ğŸŠ Can you do?

  1. Identify the type of conditional in each sentence: a. If you heat water to 100Â°C, it boils. b. If it rains tomorrow, we will cancel the picnic. c. If I had more time, I would learn to play the piano. d. If she had studied harder, she would have passed the exam.

  2. Complete the sentences with the correct verb forms: a. If I _______ (win) the lottery, I _______ (buy) a house by the beach. b. If she _______ (not/hurry), she _______ (miss) the train. c. If we _______ (know) about the problem earlier, we _______ (can/fix) it. d. Water _______ (freeze) if the temperature _______ (fall) below 0Â°C.

  3. Rewrite these sentences using the conditional type indicated: a. I don't have enough money, so I can't buy a new car. (second conditional) b. She didn't call me, so I didn't know about the party. (third conditional) c. When people eat too much sugar, they gain weight. (zero conditional) d. I will help you if you ask me. (first conditional)

  4. Choose the correct form to complete each conditional sentence: a. If I _______ the answer, I would tell you. i. know ii. knew iii. had known

    b. If you had told me about the meeting, I _______ it. i. wouldn't miss ii. wouldn't have missed iii. won't miss

    c. If it _______ tomorrow, the match will be postponed. i. rains ii. will rain iii. rained

ğŸ” Deep Dive

Conditional sentences are essential for expressing hypothetical situations and their consequences. Let's explore each type in detail, with special attention to aspects that often challenge Brazilian English learners.

Zero Conditional

The zero conditional expresses general truths, scientific facts, or things that always happen under certain conditions.

Structure: If + present simple, present simple

Examples:

  • If you heat ice, it melts.

  • If you don't water plants, they die.

  • If you mix blue and yellow, you get green.

  • Water boils if you heat it to 100Â°C.

Alternative Forms:

  • When/Whenever can often replace "if" in zero conditionals:

    • When you heat ice, it melts.

    • Whenever it rains, the garden looks beautiful.

Usage:

  • Scientific facts and natural laws

  • General truths and habitual results

  • Instructions and procedures

  • Definite or inevitable results

Note for Brazilian Learners: In Portuguese, the present tense is also used for both clauses in this type of conditional, making it relatively straightforward to translate:

  • English: If you heat water, it boils.

  • Portuguese: Se vocÃª esquenta Ã¡gua, ela ferve.

First Conditional

The first conditional expresses real or possible situations in the future and their likely results.

Structure: If + present simple, will/can/may/might + base verb

Examples:

  • If it rains tomorrow, we will cancel the picnic.

  • If you study hard, you will pass the exam.

  • If she arrives late, we can start without her.

  • If you don't hurry, you might miss the train.

Alternative Forms:

  • Unless (= if not):

    • Unless you hurry, you'll miss the train. (= If you don't hurry, you'll miss the train.)

  • As long as, provided that, on condition that:

    • I'll lend you the money provided that you pay me back next month.

  • Imperative + and/or:

    • Hurry up or you'll miss the train. (= If you don't hurry up, you'll miss the train.)

    • Study hard and you'll pass the exam. (= If you study hard, you'll pass the exam.)

Usage:

  • Likely or possible future situations

  • Warnings and threats

  • Promises and offers

  • Predictions based on current evidence

Note for Brazilian Learners: In Portuguese, the future subjunctive is often used in the "if" clause, which doesn't exist in English:

  • English: If it rains tomorrow, we will cancel the picnic.

  • Portuguese: Se chover amanhÃ£, cancelaremos o piquenique.

This difference can lead to errors like "If it will rain tomorrow..." which is incorrect in English.

Second Conditional

The second conditional expresses hypothetical, unlikely, or impossible situations in the present or future and their probable results.

Structure: If + past simple, would/could/might + base verb

Examples:

  • If I had more time, I would learn to play the piano.

  • If she knew the answer, she would tell you.

  • If we lived near the beach, we could go swimming every day.

  • If I won the lottery, I might travel around the world.

Special Case with "Were": In formal English, "were" is used instead of "was" for all persons in second conditionals:

  • If I were rich, I would buy a yacht. (more formal)

  • If I was rich, I would buy a yacht. (less formal)

This is one of the few remaining examples of the subjunctive mood in English.

Alternative Forms:

  • Wish + past simple (for present wishes):

    • I wish I had more time. (= If I had more time, it would be good.)

  • If only:

    • If only I knew the answer! (= I really wish I knew the answer.)

Usage:

  • Hypothetical or unlikely present/future situations

  • Giving advice (If I were you...)

  • Imagining different present realities

  • Polite requests and suggestions

Note for Brazilian Learners: In Portuguese, the imperfect subjunctive is used in the "if" clause and the conditional tense in the result clause:

  • English: If I had more money, I would buy a new car.

  • Portuguese: Se eu tivesse mais dinheiro, compraria um carro novo.

The tense correspondence is similar, making this conditional relatively straightforward for Brazilian learners.

Third Conditional

The third conditional expresses hypothetical situations in the past (things that didn't happen) and their imagined results.

Structure: If + past perfect, would/could/might + have + past participle

Examples:

  • If she had studied harder, she would have passed the exam.

  • If I had known about the party, I would have gone.

  • If we hadn't missed the train, we could have arrived on time.

  • If you had told me earlier, I might have been able to help.

Alternative Forms:

  • Wish + past perfect (for past regrets):

    • I wish I had studied harder. (= If I had studied harder, it would have been better.)

  • If only:

    • If only I had known about the meeting! (= I really regret not knowing about the meeting.)

Usage:

  • Expressing regrets about the past

  • Speculating about different past outcomes

  • Assigning responsibility or blame

  • Discussing missed opportunities

Note for Brazilian Learners: In Portuguese, the pluperfect subjunctive is used in the "if" clause and the perfect conditional in the result clause:

  • English: If I had seen you, I would have said hello.

  • Portuguese: Se eu tivesse te visto, teria dito olÃ¡.

The structure is similar, but the formation of the past perfect and perfect conditional can be challenging for Brazilian learners.

Mixed Conditionals

Mixed conditionals combine different time references, typically connecting a past condition to a present result or a present condition to a past result.

Structure 1: Past condition â†’ Present result If + past perfect, would/could/might + base verb

Examples:

  • If I had studied medicine, I would be a doctor now. (past condition, present result)

  • If she hadn't moved to London, she wouldn't be working for that company. (past condition, present result)

  • If we had invested in that company, we could be rich now. (past condition, present result)

Structure 2: Present condition â†’ Past result If + past simple, would/could/might + have + past participle

Examples:

  • If I knew her number, I would have called her yesterday. (present condition, past result)

  • If he were more reliable, I would have asked him to help. (present condition, past result)

  • If she weren't so busy, she could have attended the meeting last week. (present condition, past result)

Usage:

  • Connecting past actions to present situations

  • Expressing how present circumstances affected past actions

  • Discussing ongoing consequences of past actions

  • Explaining current situations resulting from past decisions

Note for Brazilian Learners: Mixed conditionals can be particularly challenging because they don't follow a single pattern and require understanding how different time frames interact. Portuguese has similar constructions, but the tense combinations may differ:

  • English: If I had saved money, I would be traveling now.

  • Portuguese: Se eu tivesse economizado dinheiro, estaria viajando agora.

Other Conditional Forms

Inverted Conditionals: In formal English, "if" can be omitted and the auxiliary verb placed before the subject:

  • Had I known, I would have called you. (= If I had known, I would have called you.)

  • Were she here, she would help us. (= If she were here, she would help us.)

  • Should you need any assistance, please contact us. (= If you should need any assistance, please contact us.)

Implied Conditionals: Sometimes the conditional is implied rather than stated explicitly:

  • Without your help, we wouldn't have succeeded. (= If you hadn't helped us, we wouldn't have succeeded.)

  • But for the rain, we would have had a perfect day. (= If it hadn't rained, we would have had a perfect day.)

Conditionals with Modal Verbs: Modal verbs add nuance to conditional sentences:

  • If you study hard, you might pass the exam. (possibility)

  • If you had asked me, I could have helped you. (ability)

  • If it rains, we should stay home. (recommendation)

  • If I were you, I would apply for that job. (advice)

Conditionals without "If": Several structures can replace "if" in conditional sentences:

  • Suppose/Supposing: Suppose you won the lottery, what would you do?

  • What if: What if we tried a different approach?

  • Otherwise: Hurry up, otherwise you'll be late.

  • Or else: Be quiet, or else you'll wake the baby.

  • In case: Take an umbrella in case it rains.

Common Challenges for Brazilian Learners

1. Future Tense in "If" Clauses: In English, we don't use "will" in the "if" clause of first conditionals, while in Portuguese, the future subjunctive is used:

  • Incorrect: If it will rain tomorrow, we will cancel the picnic.

  • Correct: If it rains tomorrow, we will cancel the picnic.

  • Portuguese: Se chover amanhÃ£, cancelaremos o piquenique. (future subjunctive)

2. "Would" in "If" Clauses: Similarly, "would" is not used in the "if" clause of second conditionals:

  • Incorrect: If I would have time, I would help you.

  • Correct: If I had time, I would help you.

  • Portuguese: Se eu tivesse tempo, eu te ajudaria.

3. Tense Sequence: The specific combination of tenses in each conditional type must be followed:

  • Incorrect: If I would know the answer, I will tell you.

  • Correct: If I knew the answer, I would tell you.

4. "Were" vs. "Was": In formal English, "were" is used for all persons in second conditionals, which can be confusing:

  • Formal: If I were you, I would accept the offer.

  • Less formal: If I was you, I would accept the offer.

5. Translating "Se": The Portuguese "se" can be translated as "if," "whether," or even omitted in certain contexts:

  • If: Se chover, ficarei em casa. (If it rains, I'll stay home.)

  • Whether: NÃ£o sei se ele virÃ¡. (I don't know whether he will come.)

6. Conditional Perfect: The formation and use of perfect conditionals (would have + past participle) can be challenging:

  • Incorrect: If I had known, I would told you.

  • Correct: If I had known, I would have told you.

7. Unless vs. If Not: Understanding the difference between "unless" and "if not":

  • Unless you hurry, you'll miss the train. (= If you don't hurry, you'll miss the train.)

Mini Dialogues:

  1. Situation: Career Advice

    • Friend A: I'm not sure whether to accept the job offer in SÃ£o Paulo.

    • Friend B: If I were you, I would take it. It's a great opportunity.

    • Friend A: But if I move to SÃ£o Paulo, I'll have to leave my family and friends.

    • Friend B: True, but if you don't take risks sometimes, you might regret it later. If I hadn't moved to Rio for my job, I wouldn't have met my wife.

  2. Situation: Making Plans

    • Person A: Should we plan our picnic for Saturday?

    • Person B: Well, if it rains, we won't be able to go.

    • Person A: The weather forecast says it will be sunny, but we could have a backup plan.

    • Person B: Good idea. If the weather is bad, we could go to that new indoor food market instead.

    • Person A: Perfect! And if we had gone last weekend, we would have been caught in that terrible storm.

  3. Situation: Technical Support

    • Customer: My computer keeps crashing whenever I open this program.

    • Support: If you restart your computer, does the problem persist?

    • Customer: Yes, I've tried that already. If I had known it would cause so many issues, I wouldn't have installed the software.

    • Support: I understand your frustration. If you uninstall and reinstall the program, it might resolve the issue. If that doesn't work, we'll try a different approach.

Common Errors and Formal Variations:

  • "If I will go to the party, I will see her." âŒ â†’ "If I go to the party, I will see her." âœ“ (no "will" in the if-clause of first conditionals)

  • "If I would have money, I would travel more." âŒ â†’ "If I had money, I would travel more." âœ“ (no "would" in the if-clause of second conditionals)

  • "If I had studied, I would passed the exam." âŒ â†’ "If I had studied, I would have passed the exam." âœ“ (missing "have" in perfect conditional)

  • "If I was you, I would accept the offer." âœ“ (informal) / "If I were you, I would accept the offer." âœ“ (formal)

  • "Should you require any further information, please do not hesitate to contact us." (very formal) vs. "If you need more information, just contact us." (informal)

  • "Were the proposal to be accepted, significant changes would be implemented." (formal) vs. "If the proposal is accepted, there will be big changes." (informal)

  • "Had we been informed earlier, appropriate measures could have been taken." (formal) vs. "If you had told us earlier, we could have done something about it." (informal)

Conditionals in Different Contexts

1. Academic and Professional Writing: In formal contexts, inverted conditionals and more complex structures are common:

  • Should the results prove inconclusive, further research will be necessary.

  • The project will proceed as planned, provided that adequate funding is secured.

  • Were the hypothesis to be correct, it would have significant implications for the field.

2. Business Communication: Conditionals are frequently used in negotiations, agreements, and planning:

  • If you place an order of over $1000, we will offer a 15% discount.

  • In the event that the delivery is delayed, a full refund will be provided.

  • Should you wish to cancel your subscription, please notify us 30 days in advance.

3. Everyday Conversation: In casual speech, conditionals often appear in shortened or simplified forms:

  • If you're free later, we could grab a coffee.

  • What if we tried something different?

  • I wouldn't have done that if I were you.

4. Giving Advice: The second conditional is commonly used for advice:

  • If I were in your position, I would speak to the manager directly.

  • What would you do if you were me?

  • If I were you, I wouldn't worry about it too much.

5. Expressing Regrets: The third conditional is perfect for discussing regrets:

  • If I had studied harder, I would have passed the exam.

  • She would have gotten the job if she had prepared better for the interview.

  • If we had known about your allergy, we wouldn't have ordered seafood.

ğŸ“– Reading Practice

The Butterfly Effect: Small Choices, Big Consequences

Have you ever wondered how different your life would be if you had made different choices? If you had taken that job abroad, would you be living in another country now? If you hadn't met your partner, what path would your life have followed? These questions illustrate what scientists call "the butterfly effect"â€”the idea that small changes can have large consequences.

The concept originates from meteorology. In the 1960s, mathematician Edward Lorenz discovered that tiny variations in initial conditions could create significantly different outcomes in weather models. He famously asked: "Could the flap of a butterfly's wings in Brazil set off a tornado in Texas?" If the butterfly hadn't flapped its wings at that precise moment, perhaps the tornado would never have formed.

This principle applies to human lives as well. Consider education: if you study consistently throughout the semester, you will perform better on exams. But if you were to neglect your studies until the last minute, you would likely struggle, regardless of your intelligence. Similarly, in health matters, if people exercise regularly and maintain a balanced diet, they generally enjoy better health. Unless they make these lifestyle choices, they may face preventable health issues later in life.

History is full of "what ifs." If Franz Ferdinand's driver hadn't taken a wrong turn in Sarajevo in 1914, would World War I have been averted? Had the weather been different during key battles, would historical outcomes have changed? Historians often engage in such counterfactual thinking to understand the fragility of historical developments.

In business, successful entrepreneurs frequently acknowledge the role of timing and chance. As Amazon founder Jeff Bezos once said, "If we had waited six months, we would have been too late." Had he hesitated, someone else might have captured the online retail market. Similarly, if Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak hadn't built that first computer in a garage, Apple might never have existed.

Of course, we cannot know for certain what would have happened in these alternative scenarios. Unless we develop time travel, these counterfactuals will remain speculative. However, they remind us that life is shaped by countless decisions and chance events. Were we able to see all possible outcomes of our choices, we might make different decisions.

What does this mean for our daily lives? Perhaps it suggests that we should be more mindful of our choices, recognizing that small decisions can have outsized impacts. If we approach life with this awareness, we might pay more attention to the seemingly insignificant moments that could, like the butterfly's wings, set off chains of consequences we cannot foresee.

  4. What does the text suggest about how we should approach our daily choices?

  5. If the author had not mentioned Jeff Bezos and Steve Jobs, how might the impact of the text have been different?

Complete these conditional sentences with the correct form of the verbs in parentheses.

ğŸ” Deep Review

Conditional sentences are essential for expressing hypothetical situations and their consequences. Here's a summary of key points:

  • Zero conditional (if + present simple, present simple) expresses general truths and scientific facts

  • First conditional (if + present simple, will + base verb) expresses real or possible future situations

  • Second conditional (if + past simple, would + base verb) expresses unlikely or hypothetical present/future situations

  • Third conditional (if + past perfect, would have + past participle) expresses impossible past situations

  • Mixed conditionals combine different time references (past condition â†’ present result or present condition â†’ past result)

Brazilian learners often face specific challenges with conditionals:

  • Using "will" or "would" in the "if" clause (incorrect in English)

  • Translating the Portuguese future subjunctive appropriately

  • Forming perfect conditionals correctly (would have + past participle)

  • Understanding the formal use of "were" instead of "was" in second conditionals

Remember that conditionals can be formed without "if" using inverted structures (Had I known...), alternative expressions (unless, provided that), or implied conditions (Without your help...).

Quick Review Questions:

  4. What's a mixed conditional and when would you use it?

ğŸ” Review

In our previous lesson, we explored conditional sentences in English. We examined the different types of conditionals (zero, first, second, third, and mixed), their structures, and when to use each type appropriately, with special attention to aspects that often challenge Brazilian English learners.

Quick Practice:

  1. Identify the type of conditional: "If I had known about the party, I would have gone."

  2. What's the correct form to complete this sentence? "If it _______ (rain) tomorrow, we will cancel the picnic."

  3. What's one common error Brazilian learners make with conditional sentences?

ğŸ¯ Overview

Comparatives and superlatives are grammatical structures used to compare people, things, qualities, or actions. Comparatives express differences or similarities between two entities, while superlatives identify the extreme quality within a group of three or more.

English has specific rules for forming comparatives and superlatives based on the length and ending of adjectives and adverbs. One-syllable adjectives typically add -er/-est, while longer adjectives use more/most. Irregular forms exist for common adjectives like good/better/best. Additionally, English offers various structures for expressing different types of comparisons, such as equality, inequality, and proportional comparisons.

We use comparatives and superlatives to make evaluations, express preferences, highlight differences, and describe changes or trends. Understanding these structures is essential for precise communication in English, especially since they sometimes differ significantly from Portuguese comparison patterns.

ğŸŠ Can you do?

  1. Form the comparative and superlative of these adjectives: a. tall b. beautiful c. good d. interesting e. bad

  2. Choose the correct form to complete each sentence: a. This building is _______ than the one next door. i. more tall ii. taller iii. tallest

    b. That was _______ movie I've ever seen. i. the most boring ii. the more boring iii. the boringest

    c. My new job is _______ my previous one. i. as stressful as ii. more stressful than iii. the most stressful

  3. Correct the errors in these comparative and superlative sentences: a. This is the most easiest exercise in the book. b. My brother is more taller than me. c. This restaurant is more better than the one we went to last week. d. She is the intelligentest student in the class.

  4. Complete the sentences using the words in parentheses and appropriate comparative or superlative structures: a. The problem was _______ we expected. (difficult) b. As the temperature rises, the air becomes _______. (humid) c. This is _______ book I've read this year. (good) d. The more you practice, _______. (good/your English)

ğŸ” Deep Dive

Comparatives and superlatives allow us to express relationships between different people, things, qualities, or actions. Let's explore these structures in detail, with special attention to aspects that often challenge Brazilian English learners.

Forming Comparatives and Superlatives

The form of comparatives and superlatives depends on the type of adjective or adverb being used.

1. One-syllable adjectives: Add -er for comparative and -est for superlative:

  • tall â†’ taller â†’ tallest

  • old â†’ older â†’ oldest

  • nice â†’ nicer â†’ nicest

For adjectives ending in a single vowel + single consonant, double the final consonant:

  • big â†’ bigger â†’ biggest

  • hot â†’ hotter â†’ hottest

  • thin â†’ thinner â†’ thinnest

For adjectives ending in -e, just add -r/-st:

  • wide â†’ wider â†’ widest

  • late â†’ later â†’ latest

  • fine â†’ finer â†’ finest

For adjectives ending in consonant + y, change y to i and add -er/-est:

  • dry â†’ drier â†’ driest

  • happy â†’ happier â†’ happiest

  • easy â†’ easier â†’ easiest

2. Two-syllable adjectives: Some two-syllable adjectives can take either -er/-est or more/most:

  • clever â†’ cleverer/more clever â†’ cleverest/most clever

  • simple â†’ simpler/more simple â†’ simplest/most simple

  • gentle â†’ gentler/more gentle â†’ gentlest/most gentle

Two-syllable adjectives ending in -y usually take -er/-est:

  • happy â†’ happier â†’ happiest

  • busy â†’ busier â†’ busiest

  • pretty â†’ prettier â†’ prettiest

Two-syllable adjectives ending in -er, -le, or -ow often take -er/-est:

  • narrow â†’ narrower â†’ narrowest

  • simple â†’ simpler â†’ simplest

  • clever â†’ cleverer â†’ cleverest

Most other two-syllable adjectives use more/most:

  • famous â†’ more famous â†’ most famous

  • useful â†’ more useful â†’ most useful

  • recent â†’ more recent â†’ most recent

3. Adjectives with three or more syllables: Use more/most:

  • beautiful â†’ more beautiful â†’ most beautiful

  • expensive â†’ more expensive â†’ most expensive

  • interesting â†’ more interesting â†’ most interesting

4. Irregular forms: Some common adjectives have irregular comparative and superlative forms:

  • good â†’ better â†’ best

  • bad â†’ worse â†’ worst

  • far â†’ farther/further â†’ farthest/furthest

  • little â†’ less â†’ least

  • many/much â†’ more â†’ most

5. Adverbs: Adverbs ending in -ly use more/most:

  • quickly â†’ more quickly â†’ most quickly

  • carefully â†’ more carefully â†’ most carefully

  • efficiently â†’ more efficiently â†’ most efficiently

Irregular adverbs follow the same pattern as their adjective forms:

  • well â†’ better â†’ best

  • badly â†’ worse â†’ worst

  • far â†’ farther/further â†’ farthest/furthest

Some adverbs have the same form as adjectives and follow the same rules:

  • fast â†’ faster â†’ fastest

  • hard â†’ harder â†’ hardest

  • early â†’ earlier â†’ earliest

Types of Comparisons

1. Comparative of Superiority (more than/er than) Used to show that one thing exceeds another in some quality:

  • This building is taller than that one.

  • Her job is more demanding than mine.

  • They arrived earlier than expected.

2. Comparative of Inferiority (less than) Used to show that one thing has less of a quality than another:

  • This task is less difficult than the previous one.

  • The new model is less expensive than the old one.

  • He speaks less fluently than his sister.

3. Comparative of Equality (as...as) Used to show that things are equal in some quality:

  • This car is as fast as that one.

  • She is as intelligent as her brother.

  • They didn't work as carefully as they should have.

4. Comparative of Inequality (not as/so...as) Used to show that things are not equal in some quality:

  • This hotel is not as expensive as the one downtown.

  • The movie wasn't so good as the book.

  • He doesn't speak English as well as she does.

5. Superlative (the -est/the most) Used to show that something has the highest degree of a quality in a group:

  • This is the tallest building in the city.

  • She is the most talented musician in the orchestra.

  • He runs the fastest in his team.

6. Proportional Comparisons (the more...the more) Used to show how one change affects another:

  • The more you practice, the better you'll become.

  • The less sleep I get, the more irritable I feel.

  • The harder you work, the more you'll achieve.

7. Parallel Increase/Decrease (more and more, less and less) Used to show gradual change in the same direction:

  • The situation is becoming more and more complicated.

  • As the day went on, I felt less and less confident.

  • Their relationship grew stronger and stronger.

8. Comparing Multiples (twice as...as, half as...as) Used to compare quantities in terms of multiples:

  • This car costs twice as much as that one.

  • The new process is three times more efficient than the old one.

  • The small apartment is half as expensive as the large one.

Common Modifiers with Comparatives and Superlatives

With Comparatives:

  • much/far/a lot: The new version is much better than the old one.

  • a little/slightly: This phone is slightly more expensive than that one.

  • even: The second test was even harder than the first.

  • any: Is Tokyo any bigger than Seoul?

  • no: This restaurant is no better than the one across the street.

With Superlatives:

  • by far: She is by far the most qualified candidate.

  • easily: This is easily the best film of the year.

  • one of: He's one of the most talented musicians I know.

  • the very: This is the very best solution we could find.

  • the second/third: She's the second tallest person in her family.

Common Challenges for Brazilian Learners

1. Double Comparatives/Superlatives: In Portuguese, it's common to use "mais" with adjectives that already have a comparative form. In English, this is incorrect:

  • Incorrect: This book is more better than that one.

  • Correct: This book is better than that one.

  • Incorrect: This is the most easiest exercise.

  • Correct: This is the easiest exercise.

2. "Than" vs. "That": Brazilian learners often confuse "than" (used in comparisons) with "that" (a demonstrative pronoun or conjunction):

  • Incorrect: She is taller that her sister.

  • Correct: She is taller than her sister.

3. "More" vs. "-er" Confusion: Knowing when to use "more" versus the "-er" ending can be challenging:

  • Incorrect: She is more tall than her brother.

  • Correct: She is taller than her brother.

  • Incorrect: This is expensiver than that.

  • Correct: This is more expensive than that.

4. Omitting "The" with Superlatives: In Portuguese, the definite article is sometimes optional with superlatives, but in English, "the" is required:

  • Incorrect: This is most interesting book I've read.

  • Correct: This is the most interesting book I've read.

5. "As...As" vs. "So...As": In negative comparisons of equality, both "as...as" and "so...as" are correct, but "as...as" is more common:

  • The movie wasn't as good as the book. (more common)

  • The movie wasn't so good as the book. (less common)

6. Translating "TÃ£o...Quanto": The Portuguese structure "tÃ£o...quanto" translates to "as...as" in English:

  • Portuguese: Ele Ã© tÃ£o alto quanto o irmÃ£o.

  • English: He is as tall as his brother.

7. Translating "Mais...Do Que": The Portuguese structure "mais...do que" translates to the comparative form + "than" in English:

  • Portuguese: Ela Ã© mais inteligente do que eu.

  • English: She is more intelligent than I (am).

8. Position of Adjectives: In Portuguese, adjectives often follow nouns, while in English they usually come before:

  • Portuguese: Este Ã© o livro mais interessante.

  • English: This is the most interesting book.

9. Comparing Equal Numbers: When comparing equal numbers or amounts, English uses "as many/much...as":

  • Portuguese: Eu tenho tantos livros quanto vocÃª.

  • English: I have as many books as you (do).

10. "One of the" + Superlative + Plural Noun: This structure is often misused:

  • Incorrect: She is one of the best student in the class.

  • Correct: She is one of the best students in the class.

Comparatives and Superlatives in Different Contexts

1. Academic and Professional Writing: In formal contexts, more complex comparative structures are common:

  • The results of the second experiment were significantly more conclusive than those of the first.

  • Among the three methodologies, the quantitative approach proved to be the most effective for this particular research question.

  • The correlation between variables A and B was considerably stronger than that between variables A and C.

2. Business Communication: Comparisons are frequently used in business to evaluate performance, products, or strategies:

  • Our new model is 30% more energy-efficient than the previous one.

  • This quarter's sales figures are the highest we've seen in five years.

  • The more streamlined our processes become, the more competitive we'll be in the market.

3. Everyday Conversation: In casual speech, comparisons are often simplified or exaggerated:

  • This is way better than the last one.

  • That was the worst movie ever!

  • The more I think about it, the less I like the idea.

4. Advertising and Marketing: Comparatives and superlatives are staples of advertising language:

  • Our detergent cleans better than any other brand.

  • The fastest, most reliable internet service in the city.

  • Get more for less with our new value packages.

5. Travel and Tourism: Descriptions of destinations often rely heavily on comparatives and superlatives:

  • One of the most beautiful beaches in the world.

  • A more authentic cultural experience than typical tourist attractions.

  • The highest observation deck in the Southern Hemisphere.

Mini Dialogues:

  1. Situation: Shopping for Electronics

    • Customer: I'm looking for a new laptop. How does this model compare to that one?

    • Salesperson: This one has a faster processor and more memory than that one. It's also lighter and has a longer battery life.

    • Customer: Is it the most expensive model you have?

    • Salesperson: No, it's more affordable than our premium models, but it offers better value for money than the budget options.

  2. Situation: Restaurant Review

    • Friend A: How was that new restaurant you tried last night?

    • Friend B: The food was good, but not as good as everyone claimed. It was much more expensive than I expected.

    • Friend A: Was it at least better than that place we went to last month?

    • Friend B: Definitely. The service was far friendlier, and the atmosphere was the most pleasant I've experienced in a while. The more I think about it, the more I appreciate certain aspects of it.

  3. Situation: Job Interview

    • Interviewer: What would you say is your greatest strength?

    • Candidate: I'm at my best when working under pressure. The more challenging the situation, the more focused I become.

    • Interviewer: And how would you compare your current skills to what you had when you started your career?

    • Candidate: I'm much more adaptable now than I was five years ago, and I've developed a far better understanding of industry trends. Communication has always been one of my strongest skills, but even that has improved significantly.

Common Errors and Formal Variations:

  • "She is more taller than her sister." âŒ â†’ "She is taller than her sister." âœ“ (double comparative)

  • "This is most interesting book I've read." âŒ â†’ "This is the most interesting book I've read." âœ“ (missing "the")

  • "My house is more bigger than yours." âŒ â†’ "My house is bigger than yours." âœ“ (double comparative)

  • "He runs more fast than me." âŒ â†’ "He runs faster than me." âœ“ (incorrect form for one-syllable adverb)

  • "The proposed solution is considerably more effective than the current approach." (formal) vs. "This solution works way better than what we're doing now." (informal)

  • "Among all candidates, she demonstrated the most comprehensive understanding of the subject matter." (formal) vs. "She knew the most about the topic out of everyone." (informal)

  • "The data indicate that Method A is marginally more efficient than Method B." (formal) vs. "Method A works a bit better than Method B." (informal)

Special Cases and Exceptions

1. Absolute Adjectives: Some adjectives are technically "absolute" and cannot logically be compared, though they often are in everyday speech:

  • perfect, unique, complete, impossible, dead, pregnant

Formal usage avoids comparing these directly:

  • Incorrect (formal): This solution is more perfect than that one.

  • Correct (formal): This solution is closer to perfection than that one.

In informal speech, however, such comparisons are common:

  • Informal: That's the most unique approach I've ever seen.

2. Comparisons with Nouns: Sometimes comparisons involve nouns rather than adjectives:

  • She has more patience than I do.

  • They have fewer opportunities than we had.

  • We need more time to complete this project.

3. Comparison of Actions: When comparing actions, we often use verb + adverb structures:

  • She speaks more fluently than her brother.

  • He drives more carefully than his father.

  • They responded more quickly than expected.

4. Comparing Different Qualities: Sometimes we compare different qualities of the same person or thing:

  • She is more intelligent than athletic.

  • The movie was more entertaining than educational.

  • This job is more stressful than rewarding.

5. Incomplete Comparisons: In casual speech, the second part of a comparison is sometimes omitted when it's obvious:

  • This computer is much faster. (than the old one)

  • The weather is getting better. (than it was before)

  • I feel much more confident now. (than I did previously)

ğŸ“– Reading Practice

The Evolution of Consumer Technology: Better, Faster, Smarter?

Over the past few decades, consumer technology has evolved at an unprecedented pace. Today's smartphones are more powerful than the computers that guided the Apollo missions to the moon. Storage devices have become smaller yet vastly more capacious. Screens are sharper, batteries last longer, and internet connections are faster than ever before. But has this relentless pursuit of "better" technology truly improved our lives?

The most obvious benefit has been increased productivity. Tasks that once took hours can now be completed in minutes. Communication is more immediate than at any previous point in history. Information is more accessible, making education more democratic. For many professionals, work has become more flexible, allowing for better work-life balance.

However, not all comparisons yield such positive results. As our devices have become more sophisticated, they have also become more distracting. The average person checks their phone far more frequently than they did ten years ago. Social media platforms are designed to be as addictive as possible, leading to less meaningful face-to-face interaction. The more connected we become digitally, the more disconnected we often feel personally.

Privacy concerns present another area where "more" isn't necessarily better. The most convenient applications are frequently the ones collecting the most data about users. The more features a "free" service offers, the more likely it is that users themselves are the product being sold to advertisers.

From an environmental perspective, the picture is equally complex. Modern devices are more energy-efficient than their predecessors, but they are replaced more frequently. The newest smartphone might use less electricity than the previous model, but the environmental cost of manufacturing millions of new devices every year is substantial. The more rapidly technology advances, the more electronic waste we generate.

Perhaps the most concerning trend is the widening technological divide. The most advanced technologies are typically the most expensive, making them less accessible to lower-income populations. As more essential services move online, those with the least access to technology become the most disadvantaged.

Looking forward, the challenge isn't simply to make technology better, faster, or smarter, but to make it more sustainable, more equitable, and more conducive to human well-being. The most successful innovations of the future may not be those with the most impressive specifications, but those that most thoughtfully balance technological advancement with human and environmental needs.

As consumers, we face increasingly complex choices. Is the latest model significantly better than the one we already own? Will a more expensive device truly make us more productive? The more mindfully we approach these questions, the more likely we are to develop a healthier relationship with technologyâ€”one where "better" is defined not just by technical specifications, but by how technology enhances our lives in the most meaningful ways.

Questions:

  1. According to the text, what are three ways in which technology has improved over time?

  2. What negative consequence has resulted from devices becoming more sophisticated?

  3. Identify five different comparative structures used in the text and explain their function.

  4. What does the author suggest should be the focus of future technological innovation?

  5. How does the text use superlatives to make its points?

âœï¸ Practice Exercises

Fill in the blanks with the appropriate comparative or superlative form of the adjective or adverb in parentheses.

  1. This is _______ book I've ever read. (interesting)

  2. My new apartment is _______ than my old one. (large)

  3. The _______ you study, the _______ your results will be. (much, good)

  4. This restaurant isn't _______ the one we went to last week. (expensive)

  5. She speaks English _______ than anyone else in the class. (fluently)

  6. That was _______ day of the year so far. (hot)

  7. The project was _______ we expected. (challenging)

  8. He's _______ person to ask for help with math problems. (good)

  9. This method is _______ efficient but _______ time-consuming. (little, much)

  10. The traffic today is _______ than usual. (bad)

  11. This is _______ expensive hotel in the city, but not _______ comfortable. (least, most)

  12. She performed _______ than she did in the previous competition. (well)

  13. This task is _______ difficult of all. (little)

  14. The instructions were _______ clear as they could have been. (not)

  15. The new software is _______ user-friendly than the old version. (far)

ğŸ“˜ Practice 3 - Error Correction

Identify and correct the errors in these comparative and superlative sentences.

  1. This is the most easiest way to solve the problem.

  2. My brother is more taller than me.

  3. She is one of the best student in the class.

  4. This restaurant has the more delicious desserts in town.

  5. The weather today is more better than yesterday.

  6. This is the beautifulest view I've ever seen.

  7. He speaks English more fluently than French.

  8. This book is more interesting that the one I read last week.

  9. She is the most happiest person I know.

  10. This computer is more cheaper than the other model.

  11. He is one of more talented musician in the orchestra.

  14. The more sooner we start, the more better it will be.

  15. This is the most highest building in the city.

ğŸ“˜ Practice 4 - Sentence Transformation

Rewrite these sentences using the comparative or superlative structure indicated in parentheses.

  1. No other student in the class is as tall as John. (superlative)

  2. This phone is expensive. That phone is expensive too. (equality)

  3. Learning Chinese is difficult. Learning Japanese is difficult too, but not as much. (comparative of inequality)

  4. As the temperature increases, the ice melts faster. (proportional comparison)

  5. This is a very good restaurant. I haven't found a better one. (superlative)

  6. Maria doesn't speak English as well as Pedro. (comparative of superiority)

  7. This hotel is expensive. The other one is cheaper. (comparative of inferiority)

  8. I gradually became more confident as the presentation continued. (parallel increase)

  9. This apartment costs $1000. That one costs $2000. (comparing multiples)

  10. No other city in the country has as many museums as this one. (superlative)

ğŸ“˜ Practice 5 - Translation Challenge

Translate these Portuguese sentences into English, paying special attention to the comparative and superlative structures.

  1. Esta Ã© a cidade mais bonita que jÃ¡ visitei.

  2. Meu irmÃ£o Ã© mais alto do que eu.

  3. Quanto mais vocÃª estuda, mais vocÃª aprende.

  4. Este livro nÃ£o Ã© tÃ£o interessante quanto o anterior.

  5. Ela Ã© a aluna mais inteligente da classe.

  6. Este problema Ã© menos complicado do que parece.

  7. Hoje estÃ¡ muito mais quente do que ontem.

  8. Este Ã© o restaurante mais caro da cidade.

  9. Meu novo apartamento Ã© duas vezes maior que o antigo.

  10. Ela fala inglÃªs tÃ£o bem quanto fala espanhol.

  11. Este Ã© um dos filmes mais emocionantes que jÃ¡ assisti.

  12. A situaÃ§Ã£o estÃ¡ ficando cada vez mais difÃ­cil.

  13. Ele Ã© o menos experiente de todos os candidatos.

  14. Este computador Ã© muito melhor que o modelo anterior.

  15. Quanto menos tempo temos, mais eficientes precisamos ser.

ğŸ” Deep Review

Comparatives and superlatives are essential for expressing relationships between different people, things, qualities, or actions. Here's a summary of key points:

  • Comparatives compare two entities (taller, more beautiful, less expensive)

  • Superlatives identify the extreme quality in a group of three or more (tallest, most beautiful, least expensive)

  • One-syllable adjectives typically add -er/-est (tall â†’ taller â†’ tallest)

  • Most adjectives with three or more syllables use more/most (interesting â†’ more interesting â†’ most interesting)

  • Two-syllable adjectives follow various patterns depending on their endings

  • Irregular forms exist for common adjectives (good â†’ better â†’ best)

  • Different comparison types include superiority (taller than), inferiority (less tall than), equality (as tall as), and proportional comparisons (the taller..., the stronger...)

  • Common errors include double comparatives/superlatives, omitting "the" with superlatives, and confusion between "than" and "that"

Brazilian learners face specific challenges with comparatives and superlatives due to structural differences between English and Portuguese, particularly with the translation of "mais...do que," "tÃ£o...quanto," and the use of articles with superlatives.

Quick Review Questions:

  1. How do you form the comparative and superlative of one-syllable adjectives?

  2. What's the difference between "as...as" and "more...than"?

  3. Why is "more better" incorrect in standard English?

  4. How do you translate "quanto mais..., mais..." into English?

Record yourself responding to these prompts, using appropriate comparative and superlative structures:
