lessons.content:
ğŸ¤¿ Ordering Food

ğŸ” Review

In our previous lesson, we explored vocabulary and expressions related to hospital and healthcare settings. We covered hospital departments, medical staff, symptoms, illnesses, treatments, and how to communicate effectively with healthcare professionals, with special attention to areas that often challenge Brazilian English learners.

Quick Practice:

  1. Name three common symptoms of the flu.

  2. What's the difference between the ER and the ICU?

  3. How would you ask a doctor about the side effects of a medication?

ğŸ¯ Overview

Ordering food in English involves more than just knowing the names of dishes. It requires understanding menu terminology, restaurant etiquette, payment procedures, and the ability to make special requests or handle unexpected situations. This skill is essential for travelers, business professionals, and anyone living in or visiting English-speaking countries.

For Brazilian learners, ordering food in English presents several challenges, including unfamiliar food items, different dining customs, tipping expectations, and variations in restaurant types and service styles. Additionally, the vocabulary and expressions used in food service contexts often contain idioms, abbreviations, and cultural references that may not be immediately clear.

In this lesson, we'll explore the language needed for various dining scenarios, from casual fast food to formal restaurants, as well as food delivery services. We'll pay special attention to areas where Brazilian learners might face confusion or misunderstandings due to cultural and linguistic differences.

ğŸŠ Can you do?

  1. Match these restaurant types with their descriptions: a. Fast food restaurant b. CafÃ© c. Food truck d. Fine dining restaurant

    i. A mobile kitchen that serves specialized food, often parked in public areas ii. A casual establishment serving coffee, light meals, and snacks iii. An upscale establishment with formal service and high-quality cuisine iv. A quick-service restaurant offering standardized meals with minimal table service

  2. Choose the appropriate phrase for each situation: a. Asking for a table at a restaurant i. "I want to sit." ii. "Table for two, please." iii. "Give me a place." iv. "I need to eat here."

    b. Ordering a dish from the menu i. "Bring me the pasta." ii. "I'll have the grilled salmon, please." iii. "I want to eat fish." iv. "The chicken for me."

  3. Identify whether these statements are typically made by the customer (C) or the server (S): a. "Are you ready to order?" b. "Could I get this without onions?" c. "Would you like anything to drink with that?" d. "Could we get the check, please?"

  4. Complete these common restaurant expressions: a. "I'd like my steak ________ (cooking preference)." b. "Does this dish contain ________ (allergen inquiry)?" c. "Could I get a ________ of water?" (container) d. "We'd like to ________ the bill." (payment request)

ğŸ” Deep Dive

Ordering food in English involves understanding different types of eating establishments, menu terminology, and the typical flow of service interactions. Let's explore these aspects in detail.

Types of Eating Establishments

Fast Food Restaurants:

  • Quick service with minimal table service

  • Food typically ordered at a counter and either eaten on-site or taken away

  • Examples: McDonald's, Burger King, KFC

  • Common phrases:

    • "I'd like a [menu item], please."

    • "For here or to go?" / "To eat in or take away?" (UK)

    • "Would you like to make that a meal/combo?"

    • "Any sauces/condiments?"

Casual Dining Restaurants:

  • Table service with moderately priced food

  • More relaxed atmosphere than fine dining

  • Examples: Applebee's, Olive Garden, Chili's

  • Common phrases:

    • "Table for [number], please."

    • "Could we see the menu, please?"

    • "I'll have the [menu item], please."

    • "Could we get some more water/bread?"

Fine Dining Restaurants:

  • Formal table service with high-quality cuisine

  • Often requires reservations and has a dress code

  • Higher prices and more elaborate presentation

  • Common phrases:

    • "We have a reservation under [name] for [time]."

    • "May I have your recommendation?"

    • "I'll start with the [appetizer] and then have the [main course]."

    • "Could you tell me about the specials tonight?"

CafÃ©s:

  • Casual establishments serving coffee, tea, and light meals

  • Often self-service or counter service

  • Examples: Starbucks, local coffee shops

  • Common phrases:

    • "I'd like a [coffee type], please."

    • "Could I get that to go/take away?"

    • "Do you have any pastries/sandwiches?"

    • "Is the Wi-Fi free?"

Food Trucks/Street Food:

  • Mobile kitchens serving specialized food

  • Usually ordered at a window and eaten standing or taken away

  • Common phrases:

    • "What's your specialty?"

    • "How spicy is it?"

    • "Do you take cards or just cash?"

    • "Could I get one of those, please?"

Delivery Services:

  • Food ordered by phone, app, or website and delivered to your location

  • Examples: Uber Eats, DoorDash, Grubhub

  • Common phrases:

    • "I'd like to place an order for delivery."

    • "What's the delivery time/fee?"

    • "Do you have a minimum order amount?"

    • "Can I pay online or when it's delivered?"

Buffets:

  • Self-service restaurants where customers serve themselves from displayed food

  • May be all-you-can-eat or priced by weight

  • Common phrases:

    • "Is it all-you-can-eat or pay-by-weight?"

    • "Are drinks included in the price?"

    • "Can I go back for seconds?"

    • "Where do I find the [type of food]?"

Common Challenges for Brazilian Learners:

  1. Restaurant Type Terminology: In Brazil, terms like "lanchonete," "restaurante por quilo," and "rodÃ­zio" don't have exact equivalents in English. Similarly, English terms like "diner," "gastropub," or "bistro" might be unfamiliar.

  2. Service Expectations: In many English-speaking countries, especially the US, service is often more proactive than in Brazil. Servers typically introduce themselves, check on customers frequently, and aim to turn tables over quickly.

  3. Tipping Culture: Tipping expectations vary significantly. In the US, 15-20% is standard, while in the UK and Australia, tipping is less expected or at a lower percentage. In Brazil, a 10% service charge is often included in the bill.

  4. Self-Service vs. Table Service: The distinction between counter service and table service might be confusing, as might the expectation to pay at the table or at a register depending on the establishment.

Menu Terminology and Food Items

Menu Sections:

  • Appetizers/Starters: Small dishes served before the main course

  • EntrÃ©es (US)/Main Courses (UK): Primary dishes

  • Sides/Side Dishes: Accompaniments to the main course

  • Desserts: Sweet dishes served after the main course

  • Beverages/Drinks: Liquid refreshments

Cooking Methods:

  • Grilled/Barbecued: Cooked over direct heat

  • Roasted/Baked: Cooked in an oven

  • Fried: Cooked in oil

  • Steamed: Cooked with steam

  • Poached: Gently simmered in liquid

  • SautÃ©ed: Quickly fried in a small amount of oil

  • Braised: Seared then cooked slowly in liquid

Meat Doneness (for beef):

  • Rare: Red, cool center

  • Medium Rare: Red, warm center

  • Medium: Pink center

  • Medium Well: Slightly pink center

  • Well Done: No pink, cooked throughout

Common Food Categories:

  • Beef: Steak, hamburger, roast beef

  • Poultry: Chicken, turkey, duck

  • Seafood: Fish, shrimp, lobster, crab

  • Pork: Ham, bacon, pork chops

  • Vegetarian/Vegan: Plant-based dishes

  • Pasta: Spaghetti, lasagna, fettuccine

  • Salads: Mixtures of vegetables, sometimes with meat or cheese

  • Sandwiches: Fillings between bread slices

  • Soups: Liquid dishes with various ingredients

  • Breakfast Items: Eggs, pancakes, waffles, cereal

Common Challenges for Brazilian Learners:

  1. False Friends and Different Names:

    • "Pepperoni" in English refers to a spicy sausage, not bell peppers ("pimentÃ£o" in Portuguese)

    • "Biscuit" in American English refers to a savory bread roll, not a sweet cookie

    • "Pudding" in British English can refer to any dessert, not just the creamy dessert known in Brazil

  2. Unfamiliar Food Items: Many common foods in English-speaking countries might be unfamiliar to Brazilians:

    • Muffins, scones, crumpets (UK)

    • Grits, biscuits and gravy (US South)

    • Vegemite (Australia)

    • Haggis (Scotland)

  3. Different Meal Patterns:

    • Breakfast, lunch, and dinner times may differ

    • The main meal of the day is often dinner in English-speaking countries, whereas in Brazil it's traditionally lunch

    • "Brunch" (combination of breakfast and lunch) might be an unfamiliar concept

  4. Portion Sizes: Portion sizes, especially in the US, tend to be larger than in Brazil, which can lead to ordering too much food.

Ordering Process and Dialogue

Making a Reservation:

  • "I'd like to make a reservation for [number of people] at [time] on [date]."

  • "Do you have a table available for [number] at [time]?"

  • "Could I reserve a table under the name [your name]?"

  • "Is there a dress code?"

  • "Do you have outdoor/patio seating?"

Being Seated:

  • "Table for [number], please."

  • "Do you have a reservation?"

  • "Would you prefer indoor or outdoor seating?"

  • "Is this table okay for you?"

  • "Your server will be with you shortly."

Ordering Drinks:

  • "Would you like something to drink?"

  • "Can I get you started with any drinks?"

  • "I'll have a [drink name], please."

  • "What beers/wines do you have on tap/by the glass?"

  • "Could I see the wine list, please?"

  • "Just water for me, thanks."

  • "Is tap water okay, or would you prefer bottled?"

Ordering Food:

  • "Are you ready to order?"

  • "Do you need more time?"

  • "I'll have the [dish name], please."

  • "How would you like that cooked?" (for meats)

  • "That comes with a choice of [sides]. Which would you prefer?"

  • "Any appetizers to start?"

  • "Would you like to hear about our specials?"

  • "Is there anything else you'd like to order?"

Making Special Requests:

  • "Could I get that without [ingredient]?"

  • "I'm allergic to [allergen]. Does this dish contain any?"

  • "Is it possible to substitute [item] for [alternative]?"

  • "Could I get the dressing/sauce on the side?"

  • "How spicy is this dish?"

  • "Is this dish vegetarian/vegan/gluten-free?"

During the Meal:

  • "How is everything?"

  • "Can I get you anything else?"

  • "Could we get some more [item], please?"

  • "Excuse me, there seems to be a problem with my order."

  • "This isn't what I ordered."

  • "This isn't cooked as I requested."

Ordering Dessert and Coffee:

  • "Would you like to see the dessert menu?"

  • "Any dessert or coffee to finish your meal?"

  • "I'll have the [dessert name], please."

  • "Could I get a coffee with that?"

  • "Just the check, please."

Asking for the Bill/Check:

  • "Could we get the check/bill, please?"

  • "We're ready for the check."

  • "Can we pay at the table or at the register?"

  • "Do you take credit cards?"

  • "Can we split the bill?"

  • "Is service included?" (asking about gratuity/tip)

Tipping and Payment:

  • "Keep the change."

  • "I'd like to add a [percentage] tip."

  • "Could I get a receipt, please?"

  • "Is there a service charge included?"

Common Challenges for Brazilian Learners:

  1. Ordering Sequence: In many English-speaking restaurants, especially in the US, drinks are ordered first, followed by appetizers, then main courses. This might differ from the Brazilian custom of ordering everything at once.

  2. Water Service: In the US, water is typically served automatically and refilled regularly. In the UK and Europe, you might need to specifically request tap water to avoid being served bottled water.

  3. Tipping Confusion: Understanding when, how much, and how to tip can be confusing. In the US, tips are usually added by the customer on the credit card slip or left in cash. In other countries, service might be included in the bill.

  4. Check Handling: In the US, the server often takes your credit card away to process payment, which might seem unusual to Brazilians accustomed to portable card machines brought to the table.

  5. Splitting Bills: Practices for splitting bills vary. In some places, it's common to split evenly, while in others, each person pays for what they ordered. Some restaurants have policies against splitting checks for large groups.

Delivery and Takeout

Ordering by Phone:

  • "I'd like to place an order for delivery/takeout."

  • "What's your address/phone number?"

  • "How long will it take?"

  • "Is there a delivery charge?"

  • "Do you have a minimum order amount?"

  • "Can I pay by card over the phone or when it's delivered?"

Ordering via App/Website:

  • Creating an account

  • Entering delivery address

  • Selecting items and customizing orders

  • Adding special instructions

  • Choosing delivery time

  • Selecting payment method

  • Tracking your order

When Food Arrives:

  • "Could you leave it at the door, please?" (contactless delivery)

  • "Do I need to sign anything?"

  • "Is the tip included or should I add it now?"

  • "There seems to be a mistake with my order."

Common Challenges for Brazilian Learners:

  1. Address Format: Giving your address in the correct format can be challenging. Remember that in English, the number usually comes before the street name.

  2. Delivery Instructions: Providing clear delivery instructions, especially for apartments or complex buildings, requires specific vocabulary.

  3. Payment Methods: Understanding options like "cash on delivery," "pay online," or "contactless payment" might be confusing.

  4. Tipping Delivery Drivers: Expectations for tipping delivery drivers vary by country and service. In the US, tipping delivery drivers 10-15% is customary.

Mini Dialogues

  1. At a Casual Restaurant

    • Host: "Hi there, welcome to Riverside Grill. How many in your party today?"

    • Customer: "Table for two, please."

    • Host: "Right this way. Your server will be with you shortly."

    • Server: "Hi, I'm Mike, I'll be your server today. Can I get you started with something to drink?"

    • Customer: "Yes, I'll have an iced tea, please."

    • Customer 2: "And I'll have a glass of the house red wine."

    • Server: "Great. Are you ready to order, or do you need a few minutes?"

    • Customer: "We need a few more minutes, please."

    • Server: "No problem. I'll be back with your drinks."

    • [Later]

    • Server: "Here are your drinks. Are you ready to order now?"

    • Customer: "Yes, I'll have the grilled salmon with the vegetable medley instead of rice, please."

    • Customer 2: "And I'll have the ribeye steak, medium rare, with a baked potato."

    • Server: "Would you like sour cream and chives on that potato?"

    • Customer 2: "Yes, please."

    • Server: "Great. I'll put that order in right away."

  2. At a Fast Food Restaurant

    • Cashier: "Welcome to Burger World. What can I get for you today?"

    • Customer: "I'd like a cheeseburger meal with fries and a Coke, please."

    • Cashier: "Would you like to make that a medium or large meal?"

    • Customer: "Medium is fine."

    • Cashier: "Any sauces for your fries?"

    • Customer: "Ketchup, please."

    • Cashier: "Is that for here or to go?"

    • Customer: "For here, please."

    • Cashier: "That'll be $8.99. Will you be paying with cash or card?"

    • Customer: "Card, please."

    • Cashier: "Great. Please insert your card when ready. Your order number is 42. We'll call you when it's ready."

    • [Later]

    • Staff: "Order number 42!"

    • Customer: "That's me, thank you."

    • Staff: "Enjoy your meal!"

  3. Ordering Pizza Delivery by Phone

    • Staff: "Hello, Pizza Palace. How can I help you?"

    • Customer: "Hi, I'd like to order a pizza for delivery, please."

    • Staff: "Sure. What would you like to order?"

    • Customer: "I'd like a large pepperoni pizza with extra cheese, and a garden salad."

    • Staff: "Would you like any drinks with that?"

    • Customer: "Yes, a 2-liter bottle of Coke, please."

    • Staff: "Great. Can I have your address, please?"

    • Customer: "It's 1234 Oak Street, Apartment 5B."

    • Staff: "And a phone number?"

    • Customer: "555-123-4567."

    • Staff: "Your total comes to $24.99. How would you like to pay?"

    • Customer: "I'll pay by credit card when it arrives."

    • Staff: "Perfect. Your delivery should arrive in about 30-45 minutes."

    • Customer: "Great, thank you."

  4. At a Coffee Shop

    • Barista: "Hi, what can I get for you today?"

    • Customer: "I'd like a medium latte with almond milk, please."

    • Barista: "Would you like that hot or iced?"

    • Customer: "Hot, please."

    • Barista: "Any flavoring or sweetener?"

    • Customer: "A pump of vanilla syrup, please."

    • Barista: "Anything to eat with that?"

    • Customer: "Yes, I'll take a blueberry muffin."

    • Barista: "Would you like that warmed up?"

    • Customer: "Yes, please."

    • Barista: "That'll be $7.50. Can I get a name for the order?"

    • Customer: "Maria."

    • Barista: "Thanks, Maria. We'll call you when it's ready."

  5. At a Fine Dining Restaurant

    • Host: "Good evening. Do you have a reservation?"

    • Customer: "Yes, under Martinez for 8:00 PM."

    • Host: "Ah yes, Mr. Martinez, table for two. Right this way, please."

    • [At the table]

    • Sommelier: "Would you care to see the wine list?"

    • Customer: "Yes, please."

    • Server: "Good evening. My name is James, and I'll be your server tonight. Tonight's specials are a pan-seared scallop appetizer with citrus reduction, and our main course special is a rack of lamb with rosemary and garlic."

    • Customer: "The scallops sound wonderful. I'll start with those."

    • Customer 2: "I'll have the French onion soup to start."

    • Server: "Excellent choices. And for your main courses?"

    • Customer: "I'll have the filet mignon, medium, please."

    • Customer 2: "And I'll try the rack of lamb special."

    • Server: "Very good. I'll be back shortly with some bread for the table."

Cultural Considerations

Tipping Practices:

  • United States: 15-20% of the pre-tax bill is standard for table service. 10% for buffet service. $1-2 per drink at bars.

  • Canada: Similar to the US, 15-20% is standard.

  • United Kingdom: Service charge (10-12.5%) is often included. If not, 10% is typical but not mandatory.

  • Australia: Tipping is not expected but appreciated for exceptional service (10%).

  • Brazil vs. English-speaking Countries: In Brazil, a 10% service charge ("taxa de serviÃ§o") is often automatically included. In the US, the tip is almost always added by the customer, even when a suggested amount is printed on the receipt.

Dining Etiquette:

  • In fine dining establishments, formal table manners are expected (napkin on lap, proper use of utensils).

  • In the US, it's common to use a fork in the dominant hand, switching when cutting food. In the UK and Europe, the fork remains in the left hand.

  • Talking loudly or on your phone may be considered rude in many restaurants.

  • In the US, servers often introduce themselves by name and check on customers frequently, which might seem overly familiar to some international visitors.

Alcohol Service:

  • Legal drinking age varies (21 in the US, 18 in the UK, Australia, and Canada).

  • ID may be requested regardless of apparent age.

  • In the US, "carding" (checking ID) is strict and universal.

  • Some areas have "dry counties" or restricted hours for alcohol sales.

Customization Expectations:

  • In the US especially, customizing orders is very common and generally accommodated.

  • Phrases like "hold the onions" or "dressing on the side" are routine.

  • In some other cultures, including parts of Europe, excessive modifications may be frowned upon.

Common Challenges for Brazilian Learners:

  1. Service Pace: In the US, service tends to be faster, with meals often completed in under an hour. This differs from the Brazilian custom of longer, more leisurely meals.

  2. Doggy Bags/Takeaway Containers: In the US, it's very common to ask for leftover food to be packaged to take home. This practice may be less common in upscale restaurants in some countries.

  3. Ice in Drinks: In the US, drinks are typically served with abundant ice unless specified otherwise, which might be different from Brazilian preferences.

  4. Free Refills: Many US restaurants offer free refills on soft drinks, coffee, and iced tea, which isn't common in Brazil.

  5. Bread Service: In the US, complimentary bread is often served before the meal. In some European countries, bread may appear on the bill.

ğŸ“– Reading Practice

Navigating American Restaurant Culture

When Paulo first arrived in Boston for his graduate studies, he was confident in his English skills. He had studied the language for years and could discuss complex academic topics with ease. However, his first few dining experiences in the United States left him feeling surprisingly confused and occasionally embarrassed.

His first challenge came at a casual restaurant near campus. After being seated, the server approached with a friendly, "Hi, I'm Jessica, I'll be taking care of you today. Can I start you off with something to drink?" Paulo was taken aback by the informal introductionâ€”in Brazil, servers rarely introduced themselves by name. He ordered water, and was surprised when the server brought a large glass filled with ice and asked if he wanted lemon. In Brazil, water was typically served at room temperature in a bottle, not automatically filled with ice.

When it came time to order, Paulo requested a steak. The server asked, "How would you like that cooked?" In Brazil, he was accustomed to meat being served "ao ponto" (medium), but he wasn't familiar with the range of options in English. He hesitantly said "normal," which led to a confused look from the server, who then explained the options: rare, medium-rare, medium, medium-well, or well-done. Paulo chose medium, relieved to have navigated that hurdle.

Throughout the meal, Jessica returned frequently to ask, "How is everything?" and "Can I get you anything else?" This level of attention felt almost intrusive to Paulo, who was used to more hands-off service in Brazil, where you typically need to signal a server when you want something.

The biggest surprise came at the end of the meal. The check arrived with the total but no added service charge. In Brazil, the 10% "taxa de serviÃ§o" was typically included automatically. Paulo wasn't sure how much to tip or how to add it to his credit card payment. He discreetly texted a Brazilian friend who had lived in the US longer, who explained that 15-20% was standard and showed him how to add it to the credit card slip.

A few days later, Paulo decided to try ordering pizza delivery. He called the number and began with "Good night," a direct translation of the Portuguese greeting "boa noite." The person on the other end seemed confused, as "good night" in English is typically a farewell, not a greeting. After placing his order, the employee asked for his address. Paulo gave it in the Brazilian format: "Elm Street, 45, Apartment 2." The employee had to clarify that in the US, the number comes before the street name: "45 Elm Street, Apartment 2."

When the delivery arrived, Paulo wasn't sure whether to tip the delivery person, as this wasn't customary in Brazil. His roommate later explained that tipping delivery drivers 10-15% was expected in the US.

Paulo's next dining adventure was at a diner for breakfast. Looking at the menu, he was confused by items like "over easy," "sunny side up," and "over hard" for eggs. In Brazil, eggs were simply "frito" (fried) or "mexido" (scrambled). He ordered pancakes, which arrived as a stack of three large, thick cakesâ€”much larger than the thin "panquecas" he was familiar with in Brazil.

At a coffee shop, Paulo was overwhelmed by the extensive menu of options. When he simply ordered "a coffee," the barista asked a series of questions: "What size? Regular or decaf? Room for cream?" In Brazil, "um cafÃ©" typically meant a small cup of strong black coffee, no questions asked.

Over time, Paulo developed strategies for navigating these cultural differences. He learned key phrases for ordering in different settings and kept notes on his phone about tipping practices. He observed how American students ordered and interacted with servers. He also discovered that most servers and restaurant staff were patient and willing to explain options when he asked questions.

Six months into his stay, Paulo felt much more comfortable with American dining customs. He even found himself enjoying aspects of American restaurant culture, like the free refills on soft drinks and the willingness to accommodate special requests. When his parents came to visit, he proudly guided them through the intricacies of ordering and tipping, explaining that understanding these unwritten rules was an important part of cultural fluencyâ€”just as valuable as knowing the right grammar and vocabulary.

Questions:

  1. What surprised Paulo about the server's behavior when he first arrived at the casual restaurant?

  2. What confusion arose when Paulo was asked how he wanted his steak cooked?

  3. What mistake did Paulo make when ordering pizza delivery?

  4. How did Paulo's understanding of "pancakes" differ from what he was served?

  5. What strategies did Paulo develop to navigate American dining customs?

âœï¸ Practice Exercises

ğŸ“˜ Practice 1 - Restaurant Vocabulary Matching

Match each term with its definition.

  1. Appetizer

  2. EntrÃ©e (US)

  3. Ã€ la carte

  4. Set menu

  5. Gratuity

  6. Check (US)/Bill (UK)

  7. Server (US)/Waiter (UK)

  8. Reservation

  9. Specials

  10. Doggy bag

a. A fixed selection of courses for a set price b. Person who takes orders and serves food c. Money given as a tip for service d. Arrangement to hold a table for a specific time e. Container for taking leftover food home f. Small dish served before the main course g. Items ordered individually rather than as part of a meal h. Main course (in American English) i. Document showing what you ordered and how much you owe j. Dishes not on the regular menu, often available for a limited time

ğŸ“˜ Practice 2 - Ordering in Different Settings

Write appropriate phrases for ordering food in these different settings.

  1. Ordering a coffee and pastry at a cafÃ©

  2. Ordering a complete meal at a fine dining restaurant

  3. Ordering a burger and fries at a fast food restaurant

  4. Ordering pizza delivery over the phone

  5. Ordering food from a food truck

ğŸ“˜ Practice 3 - Making Special Requests

Formulate polite requests for these special dining needs:

  1. You want your steak well-done.

  2. You're allergic to peanuts and need to make sure your dish doesn't contain any.

  3. You'd like extra cheese on your pizza.

  4. You want the salad dressing on the side.

  5. You'd like to substitute fries for a salad.

  6. You need a high chair for a child.

  7. You want to know if a dish is spicy.

  8. You'd like to split a dessert with your companion.

ğŸ“˜ Practice 4 - Role-Playing: Dialogue Completion

Complete this dialogue between a customer and a server at a restaurant.

Server: "Good evening and welcome to Riverside Grill. Do you have a reservation?" Customer: "______________________________ (Respond about reservation)." Server: "Perfect. Right this way, please. Here are your menus. Can I get you something to drink while you look at the menu?" Customer: "______________________________ (Order drinks)." Server: "I'll be right back with your drinks. Our special tonight is grilled salmon with lemon butter sauce." [Later] Server: "Here are your drinks. Are you ready to order, or do you need more time?" Customer: "______________________________ (Order food or ask for more time)." Server: "Excellent choice. That comes with a choice of two sides." Customer: "______________________________ (Choose sides)." [Later, during the meal] Server: "How is everything tasting?" Customer: "______________________________ (Respond about the food)." [After the meal] Server: "Can I interest you in dessert? We have a wonderful chocolate cake today." Customer: "______________________________ (Accept or decline dessert)." Server: "Would you like coffee with that?" Customer: "______________________________ (Respond about coffee)." [Later] Customer: "______________________________ (Ask for the check)." Server: "Here's your check. I can take that whenever you're ready." Customer: "______________________________ (Indicate payment method)." Server: "Thank you for dining with us tonight. Have a wonderful evening." Customer: "______________________________ (Say goodbye)."

ğŸ“˜ Practice 5 - Understanding Menu Descriptions

Explain what these menu items likely contain or how they are prepared.

  1. "Pan-seared salmon with a lemon dill sauce, served with roasted potatoes and seasonal vegetables"

  2. "Chicken Parmesan: Breaded chicken breast topped with marinara sauce and melted mozzarella, served over spaghetti"

  3. "Caesar Salad: Romaine lettuce, Parmesan cheese, croutons, and Caesar dressing"

  4. "Mushroom Risotto: Arborio rice slowly cooked with mushrooms, onions, white wine, and Parmesan cheese"

  5. "New York Strip Steak: 12 oz. grilled to order, served with garlic mashed potatoes and grilled asparagus"

  6. "Fish and Chips: Beer-battered cod with tartar sauce and thick-cut fries"

  7. "Vegetable Stir-Fry: Mixed vegetables and tofu sautÃ©ed in a ginger-soy sauce, served over rice"

  8. "BLT: Bacon, lettuce, and tomato on toasted sourdough with mayonnaise"

ğŸ” Deep Review

Ordering food in English involves understanding different types of eating establishments, menu terminology, and the typical flow of service interactions. Key takeaways include:

  • Different types of eating establishments (fast food, casual dining, fine dining, cafÃ©s, food trucks) have their own vocabulary and service patterns.

  • Menu terminology includes sections (appetizers, entrÃ©es/main courses, sides, desserts), cooking methods (grilled, roasted, fried), and specific food categories.

  • The ordering process typically follows a sequence: making a reservation, being seated, ordering drinks, ordering food, making special requests, asking for the bill, and handling payment and tipping.

  • Delivery and takeout have their own specific vocabulary and procedures, including address formats, delivery instructions, and payment methods.

  • Cultural considerations such as tipping practices, dining etiquette, alcohol service, and customization expectations vary significantly between countries.

Challenges for Brazilian learners often involve:

  • False friends and different names for food items (e.g., "pepperoni" vs. "pimentÃ£o")

  • Different service expectations and pacing

  • Tipping customs and payment procedures

  • Address formats for delivery

  • Unfamiliar food items and meal patterns

Being prepared with the right vocabulary and understanding cultural expectations can make dining experiences in English-speaking countries much more enjoyable and less stressful.

Quick Review Questions:

  1. What's the difference between an appetizer and an entrÃ©e in American English?

  2. How would you politely ask for the check/bill at a restaurant?

  3. What information should you be prepared to provide when ordering food for delivery?

  4. What is the standard tipping percentage in the United States for table service?

ğŸ  Homework

ğŸ“… Day 1 - Writing

Write a dialogue (200-250 words) between a customer and server at a restaurant of your choice (fast food, casual dining, or fine dining). Include the following elements:

  • Greeting and seating

  • Ordering drinks and food

  • Making at least one special request

  • Asking about a menu item

  • Requesting the bill and paying

After writing the dialogue, add a brief explanation (50-75 words) of any cultural differences you included between Brazilian and English-speaking dining customs.

ğŸ“… Day 2 - Listening

Find a video online (e.g., YouTube, TV show clip) depicting a restaurant scene in English. Watch it and list 10-15 new food-related vocabulary words or expressions you learned. Write down the word/expression, its meaning, and the context in which it was used.

Additionally, note any cultural aspects of dining that you observed in the video that differ from Brazilian customs.

ğŸ“… Day 3 - Grammar

Rewrite these sentences to be more natural or appropriate for a restaurant context:

  1. "I want a steak."

  2. "Bring me the menu."

  3. "I don't like this food."

  4. "Where is the bathroom?"

  5. "Give me the bill."

  6. "I need water."

  7. "This food has too much salt."

  8. "I am with hunger."

  9. "Do you accept card?"

  10. "Can I have a coffee with milk?"

ğŸ“… Day 4 - Speaking

Record yourself in the following scenarios (30-60 seconds each):

  1. Making a reservation by phone for a party of four at 7:30 PM on Saturday

  2. Ordering a complete meal (drink, appetizer, main course) at a restaurant

  3. Explaining to a server that you have a food allergy

  4. Asking questions about items on a menu

  5. Ordering food for delivery

Listen to your recordings and evaluate your clarity, politeness, and use of appropriate vocabulary.

ğŸ“… Day 5 - Vocabulary/Context

Create a personal restaurant phrasebook with at least 5 phrases for each of these categories:

  1. Making reservations

  2. Ordering drinks

  3. Ordering food

  4. Making special requests

  5. Asking about menu items

  6. Requesting the bill and paying

  7. Dealing with problems

  8. Ordering delivery or takeout

For each phrase, note:

  • The formality level

  • Any equivalent or similar expression in Portuguese

  • Any cultural notes about its usage

ğŸ“… Day 6 - Creativity/Reflection

Choose one option:

  1. Write a short story (250-300 words) about a Brazilian character experiencing confusion or misunderstanding when dining in an English-speaking country. Include at least 5 specific examples of cultural or linguistic differences.

  2. Write a reflection (250-300 words) comparing dining customs in Brazil versus English-speaking countries. Discuss service styles, tipping practices, menu terminology, and communication patterns.

lessons.content:
ğŸ¤¿ There be

ğŸ” Review

In our previous lesson, we explored vocabulary and expressions related to ordering food in English. We covered different types of eating establishments, menu terminology, the ordering process, and cultural considerations, with special attention to areas that often challenge Brazilian English learners.

Quick Practice:

  1. What's the difference between an appetizer and an entrÃ©e in American English?

  2. How would you politely ask for the check/bill at a restaurant?

  3. What is the standard tipping percentage in the United States for table service?

ğŸ¯ Overview

The "there be" structure (there is/are/was/were) is one of the most versatile and frequently used constructions in English. While Brazilian learners are typically introduced to its basic forms early in their studies, mastering its advanced uses presents significant challenges, especially since the equivalent structures in Portuguese ("hÃ¡," "existe," "tem") follow different patterns and restrictions.

In this lesson, we'll explore the more complex applications of "there be," including its various tense forms, negative and question structures, formal and informal variations, and specialized uses in academic and professional contexts. We'll also examine how "there be" interacts with quantifiers, determiners, and other grammatical elements to create nuanced meanings that often don't translate directly to Portuguese.

By understanding these advanced uses, you'll be able to express existence, location, and availability with greater precision and in a more native-like manner, enhancing both your speaking and writing skills at the C1 level.

ğŸŠ Can you do?

  1. Complete these sentences with the appropriate form of "there be": a. By the time we arrived, ________ already several people waiting. b. ________ any problems with your reservation last night? c. The researchers predict that ________ a significant increase in temperatures over the next decade. d. ________ no point in continuing this discussion if we can't reach an agreement.

  2. Identify whether these sentences use "there be" correctly. If incorrect, provide the correct form: a. There is many reasons why we should reconsider this approach. b. There seems to be a misunderstanding about the meeting time. c. There's been several attempts to contact the client. d. There appears to be no solution to this problem.

  3. Transform these statements into questions using "there be": a. There were several witnesses to the accident. b. There has been a significant improvement in your performance. c. There will be an opportunity to discuss this further next week. d. There is going to be a new policy implemented soon.

  4. Rewrite these Portuguese sentences using appropriate "there be" structures in English: a. "HÃ¡ muitas pessoas esperando na fila." b. "Existem vÃ¡rias razÃµes para essa decisÃ£o." c. "Tem alguÃ©m na porta querendo falar com vocÃª." d. "HaverÃ¡ uma reuniÃ£o amanhÃ£ para discutir o projeto."

ğŸ” Deep Dive

The "there be" structure is used to express existence, presence, or availability. While it may seem simple at first glance, its advanced applications involve complex grammatical patterns and nuanced meanings that require careful attention.

Basic Review and Common Misconceptions

Before diving into advanced uses, let's briefly review the basic structure and address common misconceptions:

Basic Structure:

  • "There is" + singular noun (There is a book on the table.)

  • "There are" + plural noun (There are three books on the table.)

  • "There was" + singular noun (There was a problem with the system.)

  • "There were" + plural noun (There were many problems with the system.)

Common Misconceptions for Brazilian Learners:

  1. Confusing "there is/are" with "have": In Portuguese, "tem" can be used to express existence (similar to "there is/are" in English).

    • Incorrect: "Have a restaurant near my house." (direct translation of "Tem um restaurante perto da minha casa.")

    • Correct: "There is a restaurant near my house."

  2. Using "it has" instead of "there is": The Portuguese "hÃ¡" (from the verb "haver") is sometimes incorrectly translated as "it has."

    • Incorrect: "It has many people at the party." (translation of "HÃ¡ muitas pessoas na festa.")

    • Correct: "There are many people at the party."

  3. Subject-verb agreement errors: The true subject of a "there be" sentence is the noun that follows the verb, not "there."

    • Incorrect: "There's three books on the table." (common in casual speech but grammatically incorrect)

    • Correct: "There are three books on the table."

  4. Overuse of "there have" instead of "there are": Direct translation from "hÃ¡" or "tem" in Portuguese.

    • Incorrect: "There have many problems with this approach." (translation of "HÃ¡ muitos problemas com essa abordagem.")

    • Correct: "There are many problems with this approach."

Advanced Tense Forms of "There Be"

Present Perfect:

  • "There has been" + singular noun

  • "There have been" + plural noun

  • Examples:

    • "There has been a significant increase in tourism this year."

    • "There have been several attempts to solve this problem."

  • Usage: To discuss situations that started in the past and continue to the present or have present relevance.

Past Perfect:

  • "There had been" + noun (singular or plural)

  • Examples:

    • "There had been many warnings before the system finally failed."

    • "We discovered that there had been a misunderstanding about the meeting time."

  • Usage: To describe a situation that existed before another past event.

Future Forms:

  • Simple future: "There will be" + noun

    • "There will be a meeting tomorrow to discuss the project."

  • Future perfect: "There will have been" + noun

    • "By the end of the year, there will have been significant changes in our procedures."

  • Going to: "There is going to be" / "There are going to be" + noun

    • "There is going to be a new policy implemented next month."

  • Future continuous: "There will be [subject] [verb+ing]"

    • "There will be people waiting for you when you arrive."

Continuous Forms:

  • Present continuous: "There is/are being" + noun

    • "There are being many changes implemented in the system right now."

  • Past continuous: "There was/were being" + noun

    • "There were being discussions about the merger when the news broke."

  • Note: Continuous forms with "there be" are less common and sometimes sound awkward. They're often replaced by other constructions.

Conditional Forms:

  • "There would be" + noun

    • "If we changed the schedule, there would be more time for questions."

  • "There would have been" + noun

    • "There would have been fewer problems if we had followed the original plan."

Common Challenges for Brazilian Learners:

  1. Present Perfect Confusion: The present perfect with "there be" doesn't translate directly to a single tense in Portuguese.

    • English: "There has been an increase in prices."

    • Portuguese might use present tense: "HÃ¡ um aumento nos preÃ§os." or past tense: "Houve um aumento nos preÃ§os."

  2. Future Tense Selection: Choosing between "will be," "is going to be," and other future forms can be challenging.

    • "There will be a meeting" (scheduled, definite)

    • "There is going to be a problem" (prediction based on current evidence)

  3. Conditional Forms: The conditional "there would be" often corresponds to different structures in Portuguese.

    • English: "There would be more opportunities if you moved to a bigger city."

    • Portuguese might use: "Haveria mais oportunidades..." or "Existiriam mais oportunidades..."

"There Be" with Modal Verbs and Semi-Auxiliaries

"There be" can be combined with modal verbs and semi-auxiliaries to express various degrees of possibility, necessity, or certainty:

With Modal Verbs:

  • "There must be" (strong probability or necessity)

    • "There must be a solution to this problem."

  • "There might/may be" (possibility)

    • "There may be a delay in the delivery."

  • "There could be" (possibility or hypothetical situation)

    • "There could be serious consequences if we ignore this warning."

  • "There should be" (expectation or recommendation)

    • "There should be clear guidelines for this procedure."

  • "There can be" (possibility or permission)

    • "There can be up to five people in each group."

With Semi-Auxiliaries:

  • "There seems to be" / "There appears to be" (perception or impression)

    • "There seems to be a misunderstanding about the requirements."

  • "There happens to be" (coincidence)

    • "There happens to be an expert on this subject in our department."

  • "There tends to be" (habitual occurrence)

    • "There tends to be more traffic during holiday seasons."

  • "There used to be" (past habit or state that no longer exists)

    • "There used to be a park where that building now stands."

  • "There is said to be" / "There is reported to be" (reported information)

    • "There is said to be a hidden treasure in that cave."

Common Challenges for Brazilian Learners:

  1. Modal Nuances: The subtle differences between modals like "might," "could," and "may" with "there be" can be difficult to grasp, as Portuguese often uses a single form ("pode haver" or "pode existir") for multiple English modals.

  2. Semi-Auxiliary Structures: Constructions like "there seems to be" or "there appears to be" don't have direct structural equivalents in Portuguese and may require completely different sentence patterns.

  3. Reported Speech Forms: Structures like "there is said to be" are often expressed differently in Portuguese, using active constructions like "dizem que hÃ¡" (they say there is).

"There Be" in Negative and Question Forms

Negative Forms:

  • Present: "There is not" / "There isn't" / "There are not" / "There aren't"

    • "There isn't enough evidence to support this theory."

    • "There aren't many options available."

  • Past: "There was not" / "There wasn't" / "There were not" / "There weren't"

    • "There wasn't any indication of problems."

    • "There weren't enough participants in the study."

  • With modals: "There + modal + not + be"

    • "There might not be enough time to complete this task."

    • "There should not be any difficulties with the new system."

Question Forms:

  • Present: "Is there" / "Are there"

    • "Is there a solution to this problem?"

    • "Are there any questions about the procedure?"

  • Past: "Was there" / "Were there"

    • "Was there a meeting yesterday?"

    • "Were there many people at the conference?"

  • With modals: "Modal + there + be"

    • "Could there be a mistake in the calculations?"

    • "Should there be more security measures in place?"

Tag Questions:

  • "There is a problem, isn't there?"

  • "There aren't any solutions, are there?"

  • "There was a meeting yesterday, wasn't there?"

Negative Questions:

  • "Isn't there a better way to do this?"

  • "Weren't there any warning signs before the failure?"

  • "Shouldn't there be more information available?"

Common Challenges for Brazilian Learners:

  1. Tag Question Formation: The structure of tag questions with "there be" can be confusing, as the auxiliary in the tag agrees with the noun following "there be," not with "there."

  2. Negative Question Intonation: Negative questions in English can express surprise or expectation, which may differ from similar structures in Portuguese.

  3. Subject-Verb Agreement in Questions: Remembering to use "is" with singular nouns and "are" with plural nouns in questions:

    • "Is there a problem?" vs. "Are there any problems?"

"There Be" with Quantifiers and Determiners

The "there be" structure frequently appears with quantifiers and determiners, which can affect both meaning and agreement:

With Indefinite Quantifiers:

  • "There is a lot of" + uncountable noun

    • "There is a lot of information available online."

  • "There are a lot of" + plural noun

    • "There are a lot of factors to consider."

  • "There is much" / "There are many" (formal)

    • "There is much debate about this issue."

    • "There are many theories explaining this phenomenon."

  • "There is little" / "There are few" (small quantity, somewhat negative)

    • "There is little evidence to support this claim."

    • "There are few options available to us."

  • "There is a little" / "There are a few" (small but sufficient quantity, more positive)

    • "There is a little time left to finish the project."

    • "There are a few solutions we haven't tried yet."

With Definite Quantifiers:

  • "There is/are + number/specific quantity"

    • "There are three main reasons for this decision."

    • "There is one exception to this rule."

  • "There is/are + all/both/neither/either/none"

    • "There are both advantages and disadvantages to consider."

    • "There is neither time nor resources to complete this project."

With Partitives:

  • "There is/are + a [number/quantity] of"

    • "There is a series of lectures scheduled for next month."

    • "There are a number of issues that need to be addressed."

Special Agreement Cases:

  • Collective nouns: "There is a team working on this project." (singular agreement)

  • Uncountable nouns: "There is furniture in the room." (always singular)

  • Plural-only nouns: "There are scissors on the desk." (always plural)

  • Compound subjects: "There are a pen and a pencil on the desk." (plural agreement)

Common Challenges for Brazilian Learners:

  1. Countable vs. Uncountable Distinction: Choosing between "much/little" (for uncountable) and "many/few" (for countable) can be difficult, especially when the countability of nouns differs between Portuguese and English.

  2. Agreement with Quantifiers: Phrases like "a number of" require plural verbs, while "the number of" requires singular verbs:

    • "There are a number of problems." (plural)

    • "There is the number of participants on the list." (singular)

  3. Positive vs. Negative Connotations: Understanding the difference between "few/little" (negative connotation) and "a few/a little" (positive connotation).

Formal and Academic Uses of "There Be"

In formal and academic contexts, "there be" appears in several specialized constructions:

Existential Statements:

  • "There exists" (more formal than "there is")

    • "There exists a correlation between these variables."

  • "There occur" (formal, for events or phenomena)

    • "There occur instances where this rule does not apply."

With Passive Infinitives:

  • "There is said to be" / "There is considered to be"

    • "There is said to be a connection between these events."

    • "There are considered to be three main approaches to this problem."

In Academic Hedging:

  • "There would appear to be" / "There would seem to be"

    • "There would appear to be insufficient evidence for this conclusion."

  • "There might be said to be"

    • "There might be said to be a paradigm shift in this field of study."

In Formal Conditionals:

  • "Were there to be" (inverted conditional, very formal)

    • "Were there to be any changes in the schedule, all participants would be notified."

  • "Should there be" (formal conditional)

    • "Should there be any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us."

In Citations and References:

  • "There has been extensive research on..."

    • "There has been extensive research on the effects of climate change."

  • "There have been several studies that..."

    • "There have been several studies that challenge this theory."

Common Challenges for Brazilian Learners:

  1. Formal Register Selection: Knowing when to use more formal variants like "there exists" instead of "there is" can be challenging.

  2. Inverted Conditionals: Structures like "Were there to be" are highly formal and have no direct equivalent in Portuguese, making them difficult to master.

  3. Academic Hedging: The use of "there be" in academic hedging (expressing caution about claims) follows conventions that may differ from academic Portuguese.

Idiomatic Expressions with "There Be"

"There be" appears in numerous idiomatic expressions and fixed phrases:

Common Idiomatic Expressions:

  • "There is no point (in doing something)"

    • "There is no point in arguing about this anymore."

  • "There is no doubt that..."

    • "There is no doubt that climate change is a serious issue."

  • "There is no way (that)..."

    • "There is no way that we can finish this by tomorrow."

  • "There is no need to..."

    • "There is no need to worry about this minor issue."

  • "There is no telling..."

    • "There is no telling what might happen next."

Expressions of Certainty/Uncertainty:

  • "There is a chance/possibility that..."

    • "There is a chance that the flight will be delayed."

  • "There is every likelihood that..."

    • "There is every likelihood that the proposal will be approved."

  • "There is little/no likelihood that..."

    • "There is little likelihood that prices will decrease."

Expressions with Prepositions:

  • "There is something about..." (suggesting a quality that is difficult to define)

    • "There is something about this painting that captivates me."

  • "There is nothing to it" (it's easy)

    • "Don't worry about the procedure; there's nothing to it."

  • "There is more to it than meets the eye" (it's more complex than it appears)

    • "There is more to this situation than meets the eye."

Expressions of Comparison:

  • "There is nothing like..." (emphasizing uniqueness or excellence)

    • "There is nothing like homemade bread."

  • "There is no comparison between..." (emphasizing difference)

    • "There is no comparison between the original and the remake."

Common Challenges for Brazilian Learners:

  1. Idiomatic Nature: Many of these expressions don't translate directly to Portuguese and must be learned as fixed phrases.

  2. Preposition Selection: The correct prepositions to use with these expressions (e.g., "no point in," "no need to") must be memorized.

  3. Register Awareness: Understanding which expressions are appropriate for formal vs. informal contexts can be challenging.

"There Be" vs. Alternative Structures

In many cases, "there be" can be replaced by alternative structures, each with subtle differences in emphasis or meaning:

"There Be" vs. "Have":

  • "There is a problem with the system." (focus on existence)

  • "The system has a problem." (focus on possession)

"There Be" vs. Subject-Verb:

  • "There are many people waiting outside." (focus on existence/presence)

  • "Many people are waiting outside." (focus on the action)

"There Be" vs. "Exist":

  • "There are several solutions to this problem." (neutral statement)

  • "Several solutions exist for this problem." (more formal, emphatic)

"There Be" vs. Locative Inversion:

  • "There is a book on the table." (focus on existence)

  • "On the table is a book." (focus on location, more literary or formal)

Common Challenges for Brazilian Learners:

  1. Choosing the Appropriate Structure: Deciding when to use "there be" versus an alternative structure based on the intended emphasis.

  2. Register Considerations: Understanding that some alternatives (like "exist" or locative inversion) belong to more formal registers.

  3. Avoiding Redundancy: In English, it's redundant to combine "there be" with explicit existence verbs:

    • Incorrect: "There exists a problem that exists in the system."

    • Correct: "There is a problem in the system." or "A problem exists in the system."

Mini Dialogues

  1. At a Business Meeting

    • Manager: "We need to discuss the project timeline. Is there any chance we could extend the deadline?"

    • Director: "There might be some flexibility, but there are several factors to consider. There have been delays in the supply chain that we didn't anticipate."

    • Manager: "I understand. There were similar issues with the last project."

    • Director: "True, but there shouldn't be the same level of disruption this time. There appears to be an improvement in the situation."

    • Manager: "That's good to hear. Should there be any further complications, how would you like me to proceed?"

    • Director: "There's a protocol in place for such situations. There's no need to escalate unless there's a critical issue."

  2. Academic Discussion

    • Professor: "There has been considerable debate about this theory in recent years."

    • Student: "Yes, I noticed there are several contradicting studies. Is there a consensus forming?"

    • Professor: "Not yet. There seems to be evidence supporting both perspectives. There might be a breakthrough soon, though."

    • Student: "Are there any researchers who have proposed a unified theory?"

    • Professor: "There are a few attempts, but there's still much work to be done. There's no telling when we'll have a definitive answer."

    • Student: "Would there be value in pursuing this question for my dissertation?"

    • Professor: "Absolutely. There's always room for fresh perspectives. There would be significant interest in a well-researched contribution to this debate."

  3. Planning a Trip

    • Friend 1: "I'm thinking about visiting London next month. Will there be good weather then?"

    • Friend 2: "There's no guarantee with London weather, but there tend to be fewer rainy days in July. There's a good chance you'll have some sunny days."

    • Friend 1: "That's encouraging. Is there a lot to do if it does rain?"

    • Friend 2: "Don't worry, there are plenty of indoor attractions. There are numerous museums that are free to enter."

    • Friend 1: "Great! Is there a particular area you'd recommend staying in?"

    • Friend 2: "There are several good options. There's no better location than the South Bank if you want to be central. There used to be limited accommodation there, but there have been many new hotels built recently."

  4. Problem-Solving at Work

    • Colleague 1: "There's an issue with the new software. There appear to be bugs in the latest update."

    • Colleague 2: "How serious is it? Are there any workarounds?"

    • Colleague 1: "There seem to be a few temporary solutions. There's a setting you can adjust that helps in most cases."

    • Colleague 2: "Has there been any response from the development team?"

    • Colleague 1: "Not yet. There's been an acknowledgment of the problem, but there hasn't been a timeline provided for the fix."

    • Colleague 2: "Should there be no resolution by next week, we might need to revert to the previous version."

    • Colleague 1: "I agree. There's no point in continuing with a flawed system if there's a reliable alternative available."

Formal vs. Informal Usage

The "there be" structure appears in both formal and informal contexts, but with notable differences:

Formal Usage:

  • Complete forms without contractions

    • "There is" / "There are" / "There has been" (not "There's" / "There're" / "There's been")

  • Strict subject-verb agreement

    • "There are several issues to address." (not "There's several issues...")

  • More complex tense forms

    • "There had been numerous attempts to resolve the situation."

  • Formal variants and combinations

    • "There exist" / "There occur" / "There appear to be"

  • Formal conditionals

    • "Were there to be any questions..." / "Should there be any concerns..."

Informal Usage:

  • Contracted forms

    • "There's" / "There're" (though "There're" is less common even in speech)

    • "There's been" / "There'd been"

  • Relaxed agreement (especially in speech)

    • "There's lots of reasons to be optimistic." (common in speech though technically incorrect)

  • Simpler tense forms

    • "There was a problem" instead of "There had been a problem"

  • Colloquial expressions

    • "There's no way!" / "There ya go!" / "There it is!"

Common Challenges for Brazilian Learners:

  1. Register Awareness: Knowing when to use formal versus informal variants based on context.

  2. Contraction Appropriateness: Understanding that contractions like "there's" are inappropriate in formal writing, even though they're ubiquitous in speech.

  3. Agreement in Informal Speech: Recognizing that native speakers often use "there's" with plural nouns in casual speech, but this should be avoided in writing and formal contexts.

ğŸ“– Reading Practice

The Evolving Landscape of Urban Transportation

There has been a significant transformation in urban transportation systems over the past decade. Where there once were limited optionsâ€”primarily personal vehicles and traditional public transitâ€”there now exists a diverse ecosystem of mobility solutions. There appear to be new innovations emerging almost monthly, from electric scooters to ride-sharing platforms, autonomous shuttles to drone deliveries.

There is considerable debate among urban planners about how to integrate these new modes effectively. There have been numerous studies examining their impact on traffic congestion, air quality, and accessibility. The research suggests there is no single solution that works for all cities; rather, there needs to be a customized approach based on each city's unique characteristics.

In densely populated metropolitan areas, there tends to be greater success with comprehensive public transportation networks. There is substantial evidence that when there are reliable subway and bus systems, there is a corresponding decrease in private vehicle usage. However, there remain significant challenges in less dense areas, where there has traditionally been heavy reliance on personal vehicles.

There have been several attempts to address what transportation experts call the "last mile problem"â€”the challenge of getting commuters from transit stations to their final destinations. There used to be few options beyond walking, but there are now micro-mobility solutions like shared bicycles and electric scooters filling this gap. There is, however, ongoing controversy about their regulation. There have been concerns about safety, with several cities reporting there were increases in emergency room visits following the introduction of e-scooters.

Should there be stricter regulations? There are compelling arguments on both sides. Those favoring tighter controls argue there is too much risk in the current unstructured approach. Those opposing regulation contend there will be less innovation if there are excessive restrictions. There seems to be a middle ground emerging, with many cities creating designated lanes and parking areas while limiting speeds in pedestrian-heavy zones.

There is also the question of equity. There continues to be disparity in transportation access across socioeconomic groups. There have been criticisms that many new mobility services primarily benefit affluent urban dwellers. There is growing recognition that there must be deliberate efforts to ensure transportation innovations serve all communities equitably.

Looking ahead, there appears to be a shift toward integrated mobility platforms. Rather than separate apps for different services, there is movement toward unified systems where users can plan, book, and pay for multi-modal journeys through a single interface. There would be significant advantages to this approach, as it would simplify the user experience and potentially increase public transit usage.

There is no doubt that autonomous vehicles will play a role in future transportation systems, though there remains uncertainty about the timeline. There have been both breakthroughs and setbacks in the development of self-driving technology. There were initially optimistic predictions that fully autonomous vehicles would be commonplace by 2020, but there has been a more sober reassessment of the technical and regulatory challenges.

Were there to be widespread adoption of autonomous vehicles, there would be profound implications for urban design. There might be less need for parking spaces, as vehicles could remain in constant circulation. There would likely be changes in land use patterns and possibly even in where people choose to live, as commuting time could be used productively.

There is much speculation about whether these technological advances will reduce or increase traffic congestion. There have been simulation studies suggesting that if there were perfect coordination among autonomous vehicles, traffic flow could improve dramatically. However, there is also the possibility that easier mobility could generate more trips, potentially worsening congestion.

What is clear is that there is no going back to the transportation paradigms of the past. There will continue to be disruption and innovation in this sector. For urban planners and policymakers, there is both opportunity and responsibility in shaping systems that are efficient, sustainable, and equitable. There can be no one-size-fits-all solution, but there is every reason to believe that with thoughtful planning and regulation, there could be transportation systems that better serve both people and the planet.

  4. What shift is occurring in how users access different transportation services?

ğŸ” Deep Review

The "there be" structure is one of the most versatile and frequently used constructions in English, with applications that go far beyond its basic function of expressing existence or presence. Key takeaways from this lesson include:

  • "There be" appears in various tense forms, including present perfect ("there has/have been"), past perfect ("there had been"), future ("there will be"), and conditionals ("there would be").

  • It can be combined with modal verbs and semi-auxiliaries to express degrees of possibility, necessity, or certainty ("there must be," "there might be," "there seems to be").

  • Negative and question forms follow specific patterns and can express various nuances of meaning.

  • "There be" frequently appears with quantifiers and determiners, which affect both meaning and subject-verb agreement.

  • In formal and academic contexts, specialized forms like "there exists," "there occurs," and inverted conditionals ("were there to be") are used.

  • Numerous idiomatic expressions incorporate "there be," such as "there is no point," "there is no doubt," and "there is more to it than meets the eye."

  • The choice between "there be" and alternative structures depends on emphasis, register, and stylistic considerations.

Challenges for Brazilian learners often involve:

  • Mastering subject-verb agreement, especially with complex quantifiers

  • Understanding the nuances of different modal combinations

  • Recognizing the appropriate level of formality for different contexts

  • Correctly forming negative, question, and tag question structures

By mastering these advanced uses of "there be," you can express existence, location, and availability with greater precision and in a more native-like manner, enhancing both your speaking and writing skills at the C1 level.
